model_answer: The preceding step most directly causing those two bot actions to occur was likely option B: Event 5: Entering the Twitter API keys into the Bots form and clicking the “Create Twitter Bots” button to start the background process. This is because creating the bots involves specifying their functionality, which includes favoriting tweets and replying to misspellings, as well as setting up the scheduling for when they should run. Once created, the bots would then begin operating according to the configuration provided in event 5.

The correct answer is C: Event 3: Creating the Twitter application by filling in the app name/description/website, agreeing to the Developer Agreement, and submitting the form.

This step created the Twitter application that was needed to generate the API keys and tokens required for the bot to access and send direct messages. Once the keys and tokens were generated, they could be pasted into the bot form on the left side of the screen (Event 5) and the bot could be configured to send direct messages (Event 8). However, without creating the application first, it would have been impossible to obtain the necessary keys and tokens.
